source.302c1a75:
#IMPORTING PACKAGES
import seaborn as sns                   #Visualization
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt         #Visualization
import pandas as pd                     #Statistics
import random                           #Generate random numbers


#CREATING A RANDOM DATAFRAME
matrix = []
for i in range(5):
  linha = []
  for j in range(5):
    x = random.randint(1,5)
    y = random.randint(1,5)
    z = random.randint(1,5)
    w = random.randint(1,5)
    linha.append([x, y, z, w])
  matrix.append(linha)
  df = pd.DataFrame(linha,columns=['Test 1','Test 2','Test 3','Test 4'],index=['Aluno 1','Aluno 2','Aluno 3','Aluno 4','Aluno 5'])
df
source.63c54ff6:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,5))
sns.barplot(x=df.index, y='Test 1',data=df)
plt.title('Nota dos alunos no teste 1',fontsize=19)
plt.ylim(0,5.5);
source.47e91ece:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,5))
sns.countplot(x='Test 1',order=df['Test 1'].value_counts().index,data=df)
plt.title('Nota dos alunos',fontsize=19)
plt.ylim(0,5)
plt.xlabel('Scores',fontsize=13)
plt.ylabel('Quantity', fontsize=13);

source.0cd61396:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
sns.countplot(x='Platform',order=df['Platform'].value_counts().index,data=df)
plt.xlim(-0.5,9.5)
plt.xlabel('')
plt.ylabel('Quantity sold',fontsize=15)
plt.xticks(fontsize=13)
plt.yticks(fontsize=13)
plt.title('The 10 platform with more sold games',fontsize=21);

#Final Graphic

palette_platform_cubehelix = sns.cubehelix_palette(15, start=2, rot=0, reverse=True)
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
sns.countplot(x='Platform',order=df['Platform'].value_counts().index,palette=palette_platform_cubehelix,data=df)
plt.xlim(-0.5,9.5)
plt.xlabel('')
plt.ylabel('Quantity sold',fontsize=15)
plt.xticks(fontsize=13)
plt.yticks(fontsize=13)
plt.title('The 10 platform with more sold games',fontsize=21);

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
sns.countplot(x='Genre',order=df['Genre'].value_counts().index,palette=palette_genre_cubehelix,data=df)

source.8b09ae0a:
palette_pub_cubehelix = sns.cubehelix_palette(15, start=3, rot=0, reverse=True)
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(19,5))
sns.countplot(x='Publisher',order=df['Publisher'].value_counts().index,palette=palette_pub_cubehelix,data=df)
plt.xlim(-0.5,9.5)
plt.xticks(fontsize=12,rotation=13)
plt.xlabel('')
plt.ylabel('Quantity sold', fontsize=15)
plt.yticks(fontsize=13)
plt.title('Avoid it!',fontsize=21);
source.b7552647:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
publi = df.Publisher.value_counts().sort_values(ascending=False).iloc[0:10]
sns.barplot(publi.values, publi.index,palette=palette_pub_cubehelix,data=df)
plt.yticks(fontsize=13)
plt.xticks(fontsize=13)
plt.title('The 10 publishers with more games sold',fontsize=21);
source.806d93c1: First, we will to plot the graphic of our data. Countplot is a graphic in format of bar, where label 'x' is the attribute choosed, and the label 'y' is the quantity found in each attribute.
source.51103ae3:
Hmmm, it's OK, but we can do **more**.

We will use the gradient color, the countplot function have the parameter '[palette](https://seaborn.pydata.org/tutorial/color_palettes.html)'.

```
palette_platform = sns.light_palette("green",10,reverse=True)
sns.countplot(x='Platform',order=df['Platform'].value_counts().index,palette=palette_platform,data=df)
```
source.dedad356:
## What is data visualization?
[Data visualization](https://www.tableau.com/learn/articles/data-visualization#:~:text=Data%20visualization%20is%20the%20graphical,outliers%2C%20and%20patterns%20in%20data.) is a useful ([and beautiful](https://visme.co/blog/best-data-visualizations/) ) way to demonstrate the data and their analysis, using [graphics](https://nces.ed.gov/nceskids/help/user_guide/graph/whentouse.asp), [chart](https://365datascience.com/chart-types-and-how-to-select-the-right-one/ps://), [color theory](https://www.dataquest.io/blog/what-to-consider-when-choosing-colors-for-data-visualization/), and [maps](https://towardsdatascience.com/tagged/maps). From that, we can to get insights to improve our analysis. The data visualization provide a acessible way to understand the data.

The data haven't the capacity to explain their analyses, they need that someone (YOU!) use the necessary abilities to get insights and know the information. The data visualization help the data scientist to tell an story ([storytelling](https://datahackers.com.br/newsletter/data-storytelling-o-que-e-onde-aprender-como-utilizar) )
source.d2307849:
Now, we can understand the information in the graphic. Then, we'll improve it.

**How to put the information in order?**

The function countplot have a parameter called "order", and how the name suggests, put the information in order.

We will add this part in our code:

```
order = df['Platform'].value_counts().index
```
But what is value_counts().index?

The function value_counts() put in order (descending), and the index select the index of this order e put in a list.
source.ed1a7673:
# Your first and easy data visualization using countplot (Python - Seaborn)

---

* This analyze is directioned for the begginers (noobs) in data science with experience in Python tools (pandas an pure python).
source.460b2c82:
## Let's code!

---

To do this, we use the followers modules:
- [Numpy](https://numpy.org/index.html): **to generate** arrays and random numbers (they represente our data)
- [Pandas](https://pandas.pydata.org/): **to import, manipulate and organize** datasets
- [Seaborn](https://seaborn.pydata.org/): **to visualize** the organized datas by easy and beautiful way
- [Matplotlib](https://matplotlib.org/): **to edit and improve** the graphics and charts created by Seaborn


The process in order:
1. [We'll generate/import the dataset](https://towardsdatascience.com/an-overview-of-importing-data-in-python-ac6aa46e0889)
2. [We'll manipulate and organize the data](https://www.marsja.se/data-manipulation-pandas-tutorial/)
3. We'll put the data in graphics, charts and/or maps and edit this.
source.e59dde26: To adjust the density of color, we substitute **10** to **15** in palette variable
source.baa3439b:
### Using real dataset (**practicing**)

---
Now, we'll use an real dataset named ["Video Game Sales"](https://www.kaggle.com/gregorut/videogamesales#vgsales.csv). This dataset is very simple and easy to work, then we can focus in the visualization.
source.020e7833:
This graph isn't beautiful or usual, it's **horrible**.

Now, we will resize the graph. And to remove the letters above the graphic, use semicolon (;) after the code.

To resize the graph, use the follow code:


```
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(width, height)
```
source.20992983: In this case, it is better to use the **horizontal** barplot
source.f3ea8caa:
Now you're talking!

We edit our graphic using matplotlib package.



1.   Delete the label x
1.   Rename the label y
2.   Write the title
2.   Fontsize of ticks (x and y)



```
plt.xlabel('')
plt.ylabel('Quantity sold',fontsize=15)
plt.xticks(fontsize=13)
plt.yticks(fontsize=13)
plt.title('The 10 platform with more sold games',fontsize=21);
```
source.8ccbecc8: Now our graph it is easy to understand
source.c27e85aa: To be beautiful, we can change the color, I like green.
source.ce4c7eae:
Now, suppose we want to limit the label x (the platforms) to 10. We use the following code:

```
plt.xlim(0,10)
```
